posts.name: Donovan White
posts.cooked:
Any teams interested in amega328p-based LED controller for 5v-addressable LED strips? I've noticed the REV Blinkit and CTRE (Cross The Road Electronics) CANdle are good LED controllers, but they're quite expensive and difficult to program or lack extensive customization. I'm wondering if developing a similar controller and selling it would be worthwhile.  

Additionally, I'm curious about the potential use of on-robot LEDs versus other applications like robot-cart lighting or pit lighting. Any feedback would be appreciated!

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: You can control the LEDs via connecting to a VRM and programming with a RoboRIO, so I don‚Äôt know what the advantage is to using something like the blinkin or Candel.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5554 - Alumni. Former head of software, strategy and development

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked: If I were you, I might reconsider using the atmega328p as it is becoming phased out and is not recommended for new designs according to Microchip.

posts.name: Donovan White
posts.cooked: I'm aware of that, just using it as an example for the concept and maybe the initial prototype.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
The PixelBlaze platform offers extremely powerful tools for configuring and installing patterns. It also provides an open-source library for custom boards.  

WLED is ESP32-based with good configuration apps and offers open-source budget options. A $5 Pi Pico is suitable for smaller projects.  

Achieving goals often involves underestimating development costs, leading to higher expenses due to high-current power management in robot environments. On non-robot applications, these costs are unnecessary, and undercutting is simple. However, cheaper standard components already exist.  

This goal may not be the best pursuit for product development as a summer project.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked:
Don‚Äôt ask me why, but I have a strong passion for addressable LEDs and controllers‚ÄîI‚Äôd even let my wife know about it.  
328p‚Äôs work fine for small setups, but they lack memory beyond a few dozen LEDs. They struggle with multiple strands unless carefully coded‚Äîthey offer a +5V logic signal.  

I recommend exploring ESP8266 or ESP32 boards. We‚Äôve successfully used an ESP8266 D1 Mini, paired with a Pololu Step-Up Step-Down Regulator to power LED strips. The ESP8266 supports custom code like WLED, which outputs only +3.3V logic, necessitating short initial LED pulses or adding a level shifter.  

For larger projects, ESP32 offers easy handling of multiple LED strips, sometimes requiring shifters.  

We managed LED control via serial packets between the Rio and controller over USB‚Äîa straightforward yet effective method.  

Aw, Tekdemo beat me to it! [Link]

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: I'm thinking of creating a project using an ESP32 chip along with SPI strips connected via a CAN Controller Area Network. However, I haven't figured out the best way to implement the control system effectively. A flexible approach would involve updating pixels at the pixel level, but this might generate excessive CAN traffic, potentially impacting critical components like motor controllers. As an alternative, I could consider setting up several preset patterns on the ESP32 without pixel-level control. Which option do you prefer, or do you have any suggestions?

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: CAN-based control and/or support for 12V LED strips. I think they also have onboard storage for LED patterns, which can reduce CPU load on the Rio, but I don‚Äôt know how much of an actual concern that is on your average robot.

posts.name: Jeffrey Morris
posts.cooked: I‚Äôve noticed the REV Blinkin and CTRE CANdle are good LED controllers; however, they‚Äôre quite expensive and usually difficult to program or lack a lot of customizability. The Blinkin firmware is open-source.

posts.name: Ryan Radtke
posts.cooked: We used PWM strips this year attached to the Rio. I believe they operated at 5V; however, a circuit designed for 5-12V could be created or purchased. For our off-board setup, we obtained an ESP32 microcontroller with a WS2812 LED strip for our driver station.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: The esp32/esp8266 controllers are preferred because they allow creating numerous animations through the Adafruit NeoPixel libraries available at github.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Welcome! You‚Äôll get a lot of advice on this topic for sure :) I can speak with a tiny bit of experience in this space. First things first these are competing goals - as you decrease programming complexity you also decrease customizability. If nothing else before outlaying money on hardware I‚Äôd recommend mocking up your development environment and user interface that hits the ‚Äúsweet spot‚Äù between these. Getting that reviewed and ‚Äúright‚Äù will be a pre-step to success. Some experience I bring to the table: I‚Äôve done very similar exercises for my own team. With no software support we‚Äôre conservatively at $29 already minimum costs with no profit margin to help you expand the business. That‚Äôs getting real darn close to Rev‚Äôs ~$50 blinkin. But then again consider that you‚Äôll have to also pay for logistics software Ongoing hardware support and Ongoing software support. Trying to break into an already competitive market with a lower-cost solution is impossible unless you have some really innovative cost reduction. IMO the easier way to break in is to innovate something that‚Äôs better than most of what‚Äôs on the market and then charge a premium for it. Especially for the LED market (where a team can always fall back on a $5 Arduino and a bit of soldering) that would be my ticket to success. ALL that being said I still encourage you to start the journey! There‚Äôs a ton to be learned even in just the initial engineering and if you do nothing but make a prototype your team can still benefit from using it next season.

link_counts.title: StatusDomeLight - Platform for creating and sharing projects - OSHWLab

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: I got this working!! I feel great about this accomplishment. I built a CAN-enabled Addressable LED Controller that's fully customizable. It supports both built-in patterns and pixel-by-pixel updates from roboRIO. Pixel-by-pixel mode can generate significant CAN traffic, so creating your own patterns in ESP32 is highly recommended. Additionally, I believe this project can be adapted for an Atmega328p using an MCP2515 chip.
